ANSWER.PARA: What direct monetary assistance or Full Time Professional Study Grants and Aboriginal Professional Study Award schemes benefit is available on an individual basis to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders under programs operating within the Minister's portfolio?
Which forms of assistance or benefits are not means tested?
How many persons received each form of assistance or benefit in 1992-93?

In 1992-93 the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) provided money to organisations which then supported individual employees through these schemes. The commitments under the Aboriginal Professional Study Award scheme were transferred to ATSIC as part of the Training for Aboriginals Program (TAP) transferred from the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) on 1 July 1992.

A formal means test is not applied to either scheme. However in awarding the Full Time Professional Study Grants the value of the study to the future development of both the sponsoring organisation and the employee is considered.
22 organisations received support on behalf of 23 employees under the Full Time Professional Study Grants Scheme. This scheme is administered from Central Office.
A Programmed Grants and Loans (PGL) report indicates that 16 Aboriginal Professional Study Awards which were previously administered by DEET were supported in 1992-93.

The Business Funding Scheme offers low interest business loans to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander individuals to engage in or acquire business enterprises that are assessed as likely to become, or continue to be, commercially successful.
The maximum level of funding for individuals per application is $500,000.
3% for loans over $50,000 and up to $100,000
6.5% for loans over $100,000 and up to $500,000.
Applicants are required to contribute a minimum of 20% equity to the business and must be able to provide adequate security for the loan.
Assistance under the Scheme is not means tested. It is a commercial loan program.

In the 1992-93 financial year $12.479m was allocated to the Business Funding Scheme. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Corporations received $12.151m and 13 individuals successfully obtained loan funding totalling $328,000.

ATSIC operates a Home Ownership Program. The scheme is targeted generally at those Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders who, because of their low income levels, often cannot obtain help from such places as banks and building societies. The interest rate for home loans begins at 5% and rises by half a per cent each year thereafter until it is 1% below the Commonwealth Bank's housing loan interest rate.
A total of 441 loans were made in 1992-93 which benefited 1,635 people.
Sport and Recreation Program, Regional Council budget

This program provides grants to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community organisations to support the sporting and recreational aspirations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. This includes funds to enable participation by individuals in sporting carnivals or to assist in purchasing sporting equipment.
This program is not means tested.

In respect of Sport and Recreation, information on individuals is not required for funding purposes at the Regional Level where acquittal procedures require information on the number and types of grants rather than information on individuals.

The Enterprise Employment Assistance Scheme (EEA), which involves wage subsidy grants to enterprises to enable them to offer jobs to unemployed Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders, was amongst those elements transferred to ATSIC as part of the TAP transfer from DEET on 1 July 1992. Many of the wage subsidy grants made by DEET under the EEA Scheme were to individual employers. ATSIC accepted responsibility for all outstanding payments in respect of those grants. Since assuming responsibility for the TAP community elements, ATSIC has not approved any new EEA wage subsidy grants to individuals.

There is no means test associated with the EEA Scheme. Employers are required to demonstrate that they are able to pay award wages to EEA subsidised employees as well as all wage related costs. They are also expected to retain the employee after the wage subsidy ceases. Answer (3).
104 people (ie. sole trade businesses) received EEA wage subsidy grants in 1992-93.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders: Monetary Assistance or Benefits

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What direct monetary assistance or benefit is available on an individual basis to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders under programs operating within the Minister's portfolio.
(2) Which forms of assistance or benefits are not means tested.
(3) How many persons received each form of assistance or benefit in 1992-93.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Social Security does not have any programs of monetary assistance specifically for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have access to pensions, allowances and benefits on the same basis as any other Australian.

The Social Security Act principles of administration refer to the need to be responsive to Aboriginality and to cultural and linguistic diversity. To achieve this, the Department of Social Security has an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Services program which includes liaison officers, Support Network for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Parents (SNAP) officers, remote visiting teams, community agents and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander interpreters.

(2) The only benefits that are not income or asset tested are the Age and Disability Support Pensions for a person who is permanently blind, Mobility Allowance, Child Disability Allowance and the Double Orphans Pension. These entitlements are available to all Australians, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

(3) It is not possible to identify how many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people received Pensions, Allowances or Benefits during 1992-93. Identification as an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person is optional when claiming Social Security payments. It is possible to obtain a figure for the number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, who have identified as such, who are receiving Social Security payments at a particular time.

For example, in July 1993 there were 40,500 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people receiving pensions, benefits or allowances from the Department of Social Security. In addition there were 25,068 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander families receiving Family Payments. In February 1993 there were 574 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander families receiving Child Disability allowance.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, upon notice, on 17 November 1993:

(b) The Central Redeployment Unit is located at 40 Brisbane Avenue, Barton, ACT. The fitout consisted of accommodation for six staff, a reception area and space for interviews/meetings.

demolition of a dry wall partition behind reception desk;
installation of reception desk;

installation of wave bar over inter-tenancy walls and 75mm acoustic batts, 1500mm wide, along tenancy walls;
installation of seal between aluminium frames and columns of inter-tenancy walls, both sides of walls;
installation of vertical drapes to all external windows;
repair to holes in walls;
repainting throughout, including walls and doors;
provision of additional power and telephone points as required;
relocation of three light fittings; and
demolition and construction of office walls as necessary.
(d) Payment made to Australian Construction Services for the work detailed above was $25,700.
